page.title: 04JAMES 'PARAFFIN' YOUNG
page.content: Scotland dominated the world's oil scene until the 1860's due to the scientific skill and business talent of a man from a poor working -class background. James Young discovered a process which enabled oil to be extracted from coal. The Bathgate hills provided a particularly suitable coal called 'Cannel' or 'Parrot' coal.(It burned like a candle and chattered like a parrot.) Young set up his business locally and when the coal supply ran out the industry switched to oil-producing shale and relocated itself at Addiewell. The industry soon reached its peak employing 13000 men. The existing towns of Broxburn, Mid Calder and West Calder grew rapidly and the new villages of Pumpherston,Winchburgh, Niddrie, LIvingston Station, Addiewell and Seafield emerged.
